Objects.Name: CreateFabClass
Objects.Description: Contains the data needed to create a new [[Class|Object|FabClass]].

Properties.Name: Name
Properties.Description: The name of the new [[Class|Object|FabClass]]. It must be unique on its own, or be unique in combination with the disambiguation text.

Properties.Name: Disamb
Properties.Description: The disambiguation text for the new [[Class|Object|FabClass]].  When provided, the disambiguation text permits the use of a non-unique name.

Properties.Name: Note
Properties.Description: A brief description of the new [[Class|Object|FabClass]]. It can be useful for helping others understand the creator's 'sintended purpose or meaning.

Properties.Name: RefinesRelatedWithArtifactId

Properties.Name: RefinesTypeWithArtifactId
Properties.Description: Identifies the [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] that refines the new Descriptor's 's[[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]].

Properties.Name: IsDefining
Properties.Description: The IsDefining value for the new [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]].

Properties.Name: Note
Properties.Description: A sentence or short paragraph describing (in a human-readable format) the intended meaning of the new [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]. A descriptive note can help others understand the creator's 'sintended purpose or meaning for the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]].

Properties.Name: UsesPrimaryArtifactId

Properties.Name: UsesRelatedArtifactId
Properties.Description: Identifies the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] for the new [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]. The related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] cannot be the same as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].

Properties.Name: Descriptor
Properties.Description: Provides Descriptor data for the new [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]].

Properties.Name: Director

Properties.Name: Eventor

Properties.Name: Locator

Properties.Name: Vector

Properties.Name: Note

Properties.Name: UsesAxisArtifactId
Properties.Description: The [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] which provides meaning for the new Vector.

Objects.Name: FabApp
Objects.Description:
A registered project, application, or business that has direct access to the Fabric API.

An App's 'sprimary purpose is to facilitate [[User|Object|FabUser]] interaction with Fabric. To accomplish this, an App typically creates an interface for its [[Users|Object|FabUser]]. This interface hides the complex details of the Fabric API, and instead provides intuitive features like custom inputs, searches, summaries, and visualizations. 

When a [[User|Object|FabUser]] becomes a [[Member|Object|FabMember]] of an App, they are granting that App permission to perform various actions on their behalf (via the App's 'sinterface). It is vital for an App to provide each [[User|Object|FabUser]] with a positive experience and do nothing to violate the [[User|Object|FabUser]]'s 'strust.

Every App has a special 'Data Provider' [[Member|Object|FabMember]], which is typically controlled by that App's 'sadministrator. The 'Data Provider' allows the App to interact with Fabric as itself (rather than on behalf of a particular User).

Every item added to Fabric is associated with (via Member) a [[User|Object|FabUser]] and and an App. Thus, Fabric can determine which App is responsible for any particular item, enforce applicable access rights, analyze the data for a particular App or [[Member|Object|FabMember]], etc.

Properties.Name: Name
Properties.Description: A unique title or identifier.

Objects.Name: FabAppDefinesMember
Objects.Description: Connects an [[App|Object|FabApp]] to all of its [[Members|Object|FabMember]].

Objects.Name: FabArtifact
Objects.Description:
An object which is able to (via [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] connections) accumulate meaning, context, user sentiment, and relationships.  Artifacts and [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]] are the central components of the Fabric architecture.

There are no restrictions on what an Artifact can represent.  Fabric encourages the generous use of [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]] to identify and describe each new Artifact. Ideally, the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] connections will distinguish an Artifact from all others.

Objects.Name: FabArtifactUsedAsPrimaryByFactor
Objects.Description: Connects an [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] to all of the [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]] using it as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].

Objects.Name: FabArtifactUsedAsRelatedByFactor
Objects.Description: Connects an [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] to all of the [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]] using it as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].

Objects.Name: FabClass
Objects.Description:
Represents any item (real, imaginary, virtual, conceptual, or otherwise) that an [[App|Object|FabApp]] or [[User|Object|FabUser]] can define and/or use to generate meaning. Classes and [[Instances|Object|FabInstance]] are closely related, and are the primary method for generating new [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]].

A Class represents a particular group, type, set, or category of items. Each Class must uniquely identifiable (via name and disambiguation) amonst all other Classes.
[(EX|Ellie's 's[[Class|Object|FabClass]] Example|Ellie is building an [[App|Object|FabApp]] for dog lovers, but there are not yet animal-related Classes for Ellie to use. She first creates broad Classes (like 'Animal', 'Mammal', and 'Canine') and relationships between them (like 'Canine is a Mammal').

She then creates narrower Classes for each dog grouping (like 'Working Dog') and breed (like 'Great Dane'), adding relevant relationships along the way. A Class named 'Boxer' already exists, but it has a sports-related meaning. She adds a new 'Boxer' Class with a 'Dog Breed' disambiguation value to resolve this conflict.)]

Properties.Name: Name
Properties.Description: A descriptive name or title.

Properties.Name: Disamb
Properties.Description: A secondary label or identifier, used to resolve unique-name conflicts.

Properties.Name: Note
Properties.Description: A summary of the Class's 'sintended meaning or purpose. This can resolve confusion in cases where a Class has vague or missing [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]].

Objects.Name: FabDescriptor
Objects.Description:
A [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] component that describes and refines the relationship between the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'stwo [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]]. Descriptors are the only required [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] component.

First, the [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]] provides semantic meaning to the relationship, such as: a A "is a" B, or C "sounds like" D. Since this relationship is directional (flowing _from_ the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'sprimary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and _to_ the related Artifact), the [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]] must coordinate correctly with the relationship's 'sdirection.
[(EX|Relationship Example|_Objective:_
Describe that a circle is a shape. 

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Circle' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Shape' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Is A' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Circle ... Is A ... Shape.)]

Descriptors also offer optional (but powerful) refinement capabilities, which allow a Descriptor to be very specific. Using any [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]], a Descriptor may refine the [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]], the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'sprimary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]], and/or the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'srelated [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]]. Note: while these [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] links are discussed here in the context of a Descriptor, the actual traversal links exist with the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]].
[(EX|Refinement Example|_Objective:_
Describe that car A and car B have headlights with a similar shape.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Car A' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Car B' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Is Similar To' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]], uses 'Headlight' to refine both [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]], and uses 'Shape' to refine the [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]

_Factor Phrase:_
Car A (more specifically, its) Headlight ... Is Similar To (more specifically, by) Shape ... Car B (more specifically, its) Headlight.)]

Properties.Name: Type
Properties.Description: Specifies the type of relationship or connection.

Objects.Name: FabDirector
Objects.Description:
A [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] component that creates a directional, action-based flow between the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'stwo [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]].

The nature of a Director's 'spathway depends on its [[DirectorType|Enum|DirectorType]]. The Director can  represent a factual, well-defined path, a virtual link, a suggested flow, etc.

A Director specifies a [[DirectorAction|Enum|DirectorAction]] for each of the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 's[[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]], which give additional meaning to the Director's 'spathway. The primary action is meant to be performed on the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] before the pathway begins. The related action is meant to be performed on the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] after the pathway ends.
[(EX|Defined Pathway Example|_Objective:_
Direct along the defined pathway of listening to a particular album's 'sthird and fourth songs (song C and D) in order.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Song C' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Song D' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'IsRelatedTo' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]].
- The Director uses the 'Defined Path' [[DirectorType|Enum|DirectorType]] and the 'Listen' [[DirectorAction|Enum|DirectorAction]] for each [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Song C ... Is Related To ... Song D. (The) Listen (action on) ... Song C ...  (leads to the) Listen (action on) ... Song D ... (via) Defined Path.)] [(EX|Suggested Pathway Example|_Objective:_
Direct along a suggested pathway of listening to song A and then learning about that song's 'svocalist, singer B.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Song A' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Singer B' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'IsRelatedTo' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]].
- The Director uses the 'Suggested Path' [[DirectorType|Enum|DirectorType]], the 'Listen' primary [[DirectorAction|Enum|DirectorAction]], and the 'Learn' related [[DirectorAction|Enum|DirectorAction]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Song A ... Is Related To ... Song B. (The) Listen (action on) ... Song A ... (leads to the) Learn (action on) ... Singer B ... (via) Suggested Path.)]

Properties.Name: Type
Properties.Description: Specifies the type and reason for the pathway.

Properties.Name: PrimaryAction
Properties.Description: Specifies the action to be performed on the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'sprimary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].

Properties.Name: RelatedAction
Properties.Description: Specifies the action to be performed on the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'srelated [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].

Objects.Name: FabElement
Objects.Description: An item (Vertex or Link) in Fabric's 'sgraph structure.

Objects.Name: FabError
Objects.Description: When a fault or error occurs, a FabError is included in the response data. The information it provides should help determine what caused the issue for the given request.

Properties.Name: Code
Properties.Description: A numeric value which identifies the specific error type.

Properties.Name: Name
Properties.Description: A descriptive name that is associated with the error code.

Properties.Name: Message
Properties.Description: A sentence or paragraph providing details about the error.

Objects.Name: FabEventor
Objects.Description:
A [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] component that applies the concept of time to a particular [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]].

An Eventor places a [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] at a specific point in time and describes why it is significant to the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]. The [[EventorType|Enum|EventorType]] provides this significance, establishing that this particular point in time is when the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] started, occurred, is expected, etc.

Each Eventor represents one particular point in time, however, the precision of that point in time can vary. The optional time values allow a point in time to provide a level of precision ranging from one second to one year.
[(EX|Started Example|_Objective:_
Specify that Albert Einstein was born (i.e. started his life) on March 14, 1879.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Albert Einstein' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Life' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Has A' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]. 
- The Eventor uses '1879' as its Year value, '3' as its Month value, '14' as its Day value, and the 'Started' [[EventorType|Enum|EventorType]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Albert Einstein ... Has A ... Life, ... (an event which) Started ... (on the) Day ... 1879 ... 3 ... 14.)] [(EX|Expected Example|_Objective:_
Specify that person A plans to attend college B in the year 2024.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Person A' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'College B' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Participates In' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]] and the 'Attend' [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] to refine it.
- The Eventor uses '2024' as its Year value and the 'Is Expected' [[EventorType|Enum|EventorType]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Person A ... Participates In (more specifically, by) Attend(ing) ... College B, ... (an event which) Is Expected (to occur) ... (in the) Year ... 2024.)]

_Note: every [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] recieves a timestamp upon creation. This timestamp is not related to the Eventor._

Properties.Name: Type
Properties.Description: Specifies the significance of this point in time.

Properties.Name: Year
Properties.Description: Specifies the year value (UTC).

Properties.Name: Month
Properties.Description: Specifies the month value (UTC).

Properties.Name: Day
Properties.Description: Specifies the day value (UTC).

Properties.Name: Hour
Properties.Description: Specifies the hour value in 24-hour format (UTC).

Properties.Name: Minute
Properties.Description: Specifies the minute value (UTC).

Properties.Name: Second
Properties.Description: Specifies the second value (UTC).

Objects.Name: FabFactor
Objects.Description:
Provides a specific piece of information, knowledge, or opinion about a pair of [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]]. Factors and [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]] are the central components of the Fabric architecture.

A Factor forms a directional relationship from its primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] to its related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]]. It contains one or more components, called Factor components. Each [[Element|Object|FabElement]] has a specific ability to refine, describe, and/or supplement this [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] relationship in a meaningful way.

There are six Factor components: Descriptor, Director, Eventor, Identor, Locator, and Vector. The Descriptor is the only required [[Element|Object|FabElement]]; the rest are optional. A Factor typically uses one or two [[Elements|Object|FabElement]], but (in very complex cases) could potentially use four or more.

Just as there are no restrictions on what a particular Artifact can represent, there are no restrictions on the type of meaning or information a Factors can provide. A [[FactorAssertion|Enum|FactorAssertion]] allows a Factor to specify that it represents (among other things) a fact or an opinion. This level of confidence for a particular [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] allows [[Users|Object|FabUser]] and [[Apps|Object|FabApp]] to more effectively find the type of information they desire.

Properties.Name: AssertionType
Properties.Description: Describes the type of information (and/or level of confidence) provided by a particular [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]. Example assertions include: Fact, Opinion, Guess, etc.

Properties.Name: IsDefining
Properties.Description: Specifies whether this Factor helps to directly and uniquely define the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].

Properties.Name: Note
Properties.Description: A summary of the Factor's 'sintended meaning or purpose. This is useful in cases when the Factor is vague, complex, or confusing. It can help resolve issues in cases where the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'scomponents inaccurately model the intended meaning. Typically, this value is not written directly by a [[User|Object|FabUser]]; the [[App|Object|FabApp]] should have enough information about a particular Factor-creating action to form a reasonable sentence or phrase.

Properties.Name: Descriptor
Properties.Description: This component defines the relationship between the primary and related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].

Properties.Name: Director
Properties.Description: This component creates a directional pathway between the primary and related [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]].

Properties.Name: Eventor
Properties.Description: This component applies the concept of time.

Properties.Name: Identor
Properties.Description: This component applies a name or identifier.

Properties.Name: Locator
Properties.Description: This component provides a geographical or relative position.

Properties.Name: Vector
Properties.Description: This component applies a numeric axis and value.

Objects.Name: FabHome
Objects.Description: The complete collection of Fabric API services.

Properties.Name: Name
Properties.Description: The name of this API.

Properties.Name: Uri
Properties.Description: The relative URI for this API level.

Properties.Name: Services
Properties.Description: The complete list of services.

Objects.Name: FabIdentor
Objects.Description:
A [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] component that applies a name or identifier to a particular [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]].

An Identor attaches a text-based value to a [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]. This value can represent a a full name, a nickname, a globally-unique identifier, a reference key to some other system, etc.

The [[IdentorType|Enum|IdentorType]] hints at the purpose or intent of the Identor. A "Text" [[IdentorType|Enum|IdentorType]] is typically meant to provide enhanced search capabilities (like finding a person by an alternate name) or some other organizational use.  A "Key" [[IdentorType|Enum|IdentorType]] is typically meant to associate a [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] with some external system (like a Product ID from an online store) or to provide an [[App|Object|FabApp]] with a "reverse lookup" for their own internal IDs.
[(EX|Alternate Name Example|_Objective:_
Identify that Grand Valley State University is also known as (has the alternate name of) 'Grand Valley'.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Grand Valley State University' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Name' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Has A' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]], and an 'Alternative' [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] to refine the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'srelated [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Identor uses 'Grand Valley' as its text value, and the 'Text' [[IdentorType|Enum|IdentorType]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Grand Valley State University ... Has A ... Name (more specifically, an) Alternative, ... (identified by the) Text ... 'Grand Valley'.)] [(EX|Abbreviation Example|_Objective:_
Identify that Grand Valley State University is also known as (has the abbreviation of) 'GVSU'.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Grand Valley State University' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Abbreviation' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Has A' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]. 
- The Identor uses 'GVSU' as its text value, and the 'Text' [[IdentorType|Enum|IdentorType]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Grand Valley State University ... Has A(n) ... Abbreviation, ... (identified by the) Text ... 'GVSU'.)] [(EX|Identifier Example|_Objective:_
Identify that game A is accessible in store B via its ID, which is '123a-45678'.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Game A' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Store B' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Is Found In' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]. 
- The Identor uses '123a-45678' as its text value, and the 'Key' [[IdentorType|Enum|IdentorType]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Game A ... Is Found In ... Store B, ... (identified by the) Key ... '123a-45678'.)]

Properties.Name: Type
Properties.Description: Specifies the value's 'spurpose or intent.

Properties.Name: Value
Properties.Description: A text-based value that can represent names, numbers, IDs, GUIDs, etc.

Objects.Name: FabInstance
Objects.Description:
Represents any item (real, imaginary, virtual, conceptual, or otherwise) that an [[App|Object|FabApp]] or [[User|Object|FabUser]] can define and/or use to generate meaning. [[Classes|Object|FabClass]] and Instances are closely related, and are the primary method for generating new [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]].

An Instance represents a singular, unique item. It may have a specific name, however, the name is not required to be unique. Instead, the creator should apply [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]] to make the [[Instance|Object|FabInstance]] as specific and meaningful as possible.
[(EX|Ellie's 's[[Instance|Object|FabInstance]] Example|_Continued from Ellie's 's[[Class|Object|FabClass]] Example..._

After completing her new [[Classes|Object|FabClass]], Ellie would like to add her own dog. She creates an Instance named 'Gulliver', and attaches several [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]] to make the [[Instance|Object|FabInstance]] as unique as possible. Her [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]] define that Gulliver is a Lhasa Apso breed, is owned by Ellie, and was born in September 2007.)] [(EX|Zach's 's[[Instance|Object|FabInstance]] Example|Zach built an [[App|Object|FabApp]] that allows users to rate restaurants and individual meals. He created [[Classes|Object|FabClass]] for restaurant chains and meal types. He also created Instances for specific restaurants (with relevant relationships for each).

When [[Users|Object|FabUser]] rate a particular meal, they also specify the restaurant, the day/time the meal was served, and the meal type. Behind the scenes, the [[App|Object|FabApp]] uses this data to construct a new Instance and its relationships. Because Zach's 'sInstances are well-defined, one [[User|Object|FabUser]] could rate the same meal (at the same restaurant) every day, creating a unique and meaningful [[Instance|Object|FabInstance]] each time.)]

Properties.Name: Name
Properties.Description: A descriptive name or title.

Properties.Name: Disamb
Properties.Description: A secondary label or identifier, used to resolve unique-name conflicts.

Properties.Name: Note
Properties.Description: A summary of the Instance's 'sintended meaning or purpose. This can resolve confusion in cases where an Instance has vague or missing [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]].

Objects.Name: FabLink
Objects.Description: A connection between one [[Vertex|Object|FabVertex]] and another.

Properties.Name: FromType
Properties.Description: The [[Vertex|Object|FabVertex]] type at the "outgoing" end of this Link.

Properties.Name: ToType
Properties.Description: The [[Vertex|Object|FabVertex]] type at the "incoming" end of this Link.

Objects.Name: FabLocator
Objects.Description:
A [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] component that positions a [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] using geographic or relative coordinates.

A Locator attaches a three-dimensional coordinate to a [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]. The [[LocatorType|Enum|LocatorType]] defines the spatial context of the coordinate, supporting both geographic and relative positioning.

Geographic coordinates represent a position on a sphere, like Earth.  They use X for longitude, Y for latitude, and Z for elevation (in metres above sea level). Use zero for elevation if it is not known or specified.
[(EX|Geographic Example|_Objective:_
Specify that person A took photo B from a spot near the Eiffel Tower.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Photo B' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Person A' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Is Created By' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]. 
- The Locator uses the 'Earth Coordinate' [[LocatorType|Enum|LocatorType]], a '2.292977' value for X, a '48.858154' value for Y, and (optionally) a '34.24' value for Z.

_Factor Phrase:_
Photo B ... Is Created By ... Person A, ... (at an) Earth Coordinate (location of) ... X (longitude) = '2.292977' ... Y (latitude) = '48.858154' ... Z (elevation) = '34.24' (metres above sea level).)]

Relative coordinates represent a position relative to the origin and size/bounds of the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]]'s 'sprimary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]]. There are LocatorTypes for one, two, and three-dimensional relative coordinates. For coordinates which have:
- One dimension, use X for time or progress, and leave Y and Z equal to zero.
- Two dimensions, use X for width, Y for height, and leave Z equal to zero.
- Three dimensions, use X, Y, and Z values which correspond to the [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]]'s 'sX, Y, and Z values. If these axes are undefined, use X for width (or breadth), Y for length (or depth), and Z for height (or elevation).
[(EX|Relative 1D Example|_Objective:_
Specify that book A refers to painting B on page 148 of 200 (about 74% of the book's 'slength).

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Book A' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Painting B' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Refers To' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]. 
- The Locator uses the 'Related 1D' [[LocatorType|Enum|LocatorType]], a '0.74' value for X, a '0.0' value for Y, and a '0.0' value for Z.

_Factor Phrase:_
Book A ... Refers To ... Painting B, ... (at a) Relative 1D (location of) ... X (position) = 0.74.)] [(EX|Relative 2D Example|_Objective:_
Specify that photo A includes person B near the top-right (25% from the top, 84% from the left) of the image.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Photo A' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Person B' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Refers To' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]. 
- The Locator uses the 'Relative 2D' [[LocatorType|Enum|LocatorType]], a '0.84' value for X, a '0.25' value for Y, and a '0.0' value for Z.

_Factor Phrase:_
Photo A ... Refers To ... Person B, ... (at a) Relative 2D (location of) ... X (width) = '0.84' ... Y (height) = '0.25'.)]

Properties.Name: Type
Properties.Description: Specifies the spatial context of the coordinate.

Properties.Name: ValueX
Properties.Description: A value representing longitude, time/progress, width, or a particular three-dimensional axis.

Properties.Name: ValueY
Properties.Description: A value representing latitude, height, or a particular three-dimensional axis.

Properties.Name: ValueZ
Properties.Description: A value representing elevation or a particular three-dimensional axis.

Objects.Name: FabMember
Objects.Description:
An association between a [[User|Object|FabUser]] and an [[App|Object|FabApp]]. The [[App|Object|FabApp]] administrator(s) can grant various access privileges to a Member by creating a MemberTypeAssign that uses a different [[MemberType|Enum|MemberType]].

Every item added to Fabric is associated with a particular Member. This enables Fabric to determine which [[App|Object|FabApp]] or [[User|Object|FabUser]] is responsible for any particular item, enforce applicable access rights, analyze the data for a particular [[App|Object|FabApp]] and/or [[User|Object|FabUser]], etc.

Properties.Name: Type

Properties.Name: Major
Properties.Description: The major revision number for this build. This value is only incremented in cases where significant or important changes have occurred. These changes may introduce backwards-incompatability with previous builds.

Properties.Name: Minor
Properties.Description: The minor revision number for this build. This value is incremented in cases when substantial functionality or improvements are introduced. It may also occur when certain functionality becomes deprecated.

Properties.Name: Patch
Properties.Description: The patch revision number for this build. This value is incremented when bug fixes or other internal changes occur.

Properties.Name: Revision
Properties.Description: The revision text is derived from internal build information. It may be safely omitted from the build's 'sversion string.

Properties.Name: Year
Properties.Description: The year that this build was released.

Properties.Name: Month

Properties.Name: Day

Objects.Name: FabOauthAccess
Objects.Description: Provides an OAuth access token and other related information. Every Fabric API request requires an access token. To include an OAuth access token with a FabricAPI request, add an "Authorization" header to the HTTP request with a value of "Bearer=[your OAuth access code here]".

Properties.Name: access_token
Properties.Description: A code that maps to various authentication information. Notably, it is refers to exactly one [[App|Object|FabApp]] and at most one [[User|Object|FabUser]].

Properties.Name: token_type
Properties.Description: For the current Fabric OAuth implementation, this value is always equal to "bearer".

Properties.Name: refresh_token
Properties.Description: A code that refreshes the authentication session for an expired OAuth access token. [[App|Object|FabApp]]-only access tokens do not include a refresh token; instead, the [[App|Object|FabApp]] should [[request a new access token|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenClientCredentials]].

Properties.Name: expires_in
Properties.Description: The number of seconds until the access token expires.

Objects.Name: FabOauthError
Objects.Description: To comply with the OAuth 2.0 specification, all Fabric OAuth requests return a FabOauthError (instead of FabFault or FabError) when errors occur.

Properties.Name: error
Properties.Description: An error code as defined by the OAuth 2.0 specification.

Properties.Name: error_description
Properties.Description: Provides specific details about the error. A single error code may have one or more possible error descriptions.

Objects.Name: FabOauthLogin
Objects.Description:
This object is unique -- the API never returns this object directly. Instead, the properties shown below are included as query-string parameters for a redirect URI. This URI is provided by an [[App|Object|FabApp]], and the [[App|Object|FabApp]] is responsible for accepting (and reacting to) the incoming redirect.

This redirect is used in one particular scenario: the [[OAuth login process|Oper|Oauth.Login]]. After the user completes this process, Fabric performs a redirect with success or failure information.  The success redirect includes the 'code' and 'state' parameters. The failure redirect includes the 'error', 'error_description', and 'state' parameters.

Properties.Name: code
Properties.Description: Use this code (also called the 'authorization code') to generate a new OAuth access token. For security purposes, each code is valid for a single use, and expires 120 seconds after creation.

Properties.Name: state
Properties.Description: Returns the 'state' value that the [[App|Object|FabApp]] provided in the original Oauth request. For security reasons, the [[App|Object|FabApp]] should reject the response if the original and returned values are not equal.

Properties.Name: error
Properties.Description: An error code as defined by the OAuth 2.0 specification.

Properties.Name: error_description
Properties.Description: Provides specific details about the error. A single error code may have one or more possible error descriptions. For use in the redirect URI, this string uses a '+' character in place of each space character.

Objects.Name: FabOauthLogout
Objects.Description: The result of an OAuth logout.

Properties.Name: success
Properties.Description: Describes the result of the logout attempt. Successful logout attempts return a value of 1.

Properties.Name: access_token
Properties.Description: Identifies a particular OAuth session.

Objects.Name: FabUrl
Objects.Description:
A hyperlink or path (uniform resource locator) to some web page, a file, or some other type of content.

While a Url is a type of [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]], it should be used with certain constraints. Consider an scenario where a Url leads to web page with a news article and a photo. The proper prodedure is to create a new [[Instance|Object|FabInstance]] for both the news article and photo. With this method:
- The news article and photo [[Instances|Object|FabInstance]] can receive [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]] independently.
- The Url should only receive [[Factors|Object|FabFactor]] related to the actual web page, its design, etc.
- Every Url that displays this particular news article can refer the same news article [[Instance|Object|FabInstance]].

Properties.Name: Name
Properties.Description: A descriptive name or title.

Properties.Name: FullPath
Properties.Description: A unique, valid absolute URL. The string must include the link's 'sprotocol (such as 'http://').

Objects.Name: FabUser
Objects.Description:
A registered Fabric account that has indirect access (via Apps) to the Fabric API. A User can become a [[Member|Object|FabMember]] of an [[App|Object|FabApp]], and then use the [[App|Object|FabApp]]'s 'sinterface to interact with Fabric. An [[App|Object|FabApp]]'s 'sinterface hides the complex details of the Fabric API, and instead provides intuitive features like custom inputs, searches, summaries, and visualizations. 

Users control their private account data and preferences using the Fabric website.

Every item added to Fabric is associated with (via Member) a User and and an [[App|Object|FabApp]]. Thus, Fabric can determine which User is responsible for any particular item, enforce applicable access rights, analyze the data for a particular User or [[Member|Object|FabMember]], etc.

Properties.Name: Name
Properties.Description: A unique username.

Objects.Name: FabUserDefinesMember
Objects.Description: Connects a [[User|Object|FabUser]] to all of its [[Members|Object|FabMember]].

Objects.Name: FabVector
Objects.Description:
A [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] component that applies a meaningful numeric axis and value to a particular [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]].

A Vector attaches a numeric value to a [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]], using an arbitrary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] to define its "axis". This axis depends entiedgey upon the Vector's 'spurpose. For example, a factual Vector might use an [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] like "Height" or "Shutter Speed". A Vector that provides an opinion might use an [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] like "Quality" or "Excitement". While the choice of an axis Artififact is not restricted, it can be beneficial to use [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]] which are other [[Apps|Object|FabApp]] or [[Users|Object|FabUser]] are already using as Vector axes. Note: while the axis [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] link is discussed here in the context of a Vector, the actual traversal link exists with the [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]].

The [[VectorType|Enum|VectorType]] provides boundaries and context for the Vector's 'svalue. It can identify the value as a percentage, a level of agreement or disagreement, an opinion-based rating, or simply a plain numeric value. Each [[VectorType|Enum|VectorType]] provides additional information, such as a [[VectorRange|Enum|VectorRange]], to provide further meaning for the levels within the the allowed value boundaries.

A Vector's 'snumeric value often reflects a measurement or a has a specific unit. Furthermore, a Vector can use [[VectorUnitPrefix|Enum|VectorUnitPrefix]] to specify an order of magnitude for the value. A Vector's 'svalue is a long integer, so the prefix is especially useful when fractional values are involved, or when the desired number is larger than a long integer.
[(EX|Small Value Example|_Objective:_
Specify that image A (which is a photo) has a shutter speed of 1/250 second.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Image A' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Photo' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Is A' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]. 
- The Vector uses the 'Shutter Speed' [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] as the axis, the 'Positive Long' [[VectorType|Enum|VectorType]], '4' as the value, the 'Milli' [[VectorUnitPrefix|Enum|VectorUnitPrefix]], and the 'Second' [[VectorUnit|Enum|VectorUnit]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Image A ... Is A ... Photo, ... (which, along the) Shutter Speed (axis) ... (with a) Positive Long (numerical range), ... (has a value) '4' ... Milli ... Second(s).)] [(EX|Large Value Example|_Objective:_
Specify that Earth and the Andromeda Galaxy are 2.5 million light years (2.2705 x 10^22 metres) apart.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Earth' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Andromeda Galaxy' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Is Related To' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]. 
- The Vector uses the 'Distance' [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] as the axis, the 'Positive Long' [[VectorType|Enum|VectorType]], '22,705' as the value, the 'Exa' [[VectorUnitPrefix|Enum|VectorUnitPrefix]] (represents 10^18), and the 'Metre' [[VectorUnit|Enum|VectorUnit]].

_Factor Phrase:_
Earth ... Is Related To ... Andromeda Galaxy, ... (which, along the) Distance (axis) ... (with a) Positive Long (numerical range), ... (has a value) '22,705' ... Exa ... Metre(s).)] [(EX|Negative Value Example|_Objective:_
Specify that article A mentions person B in a very unfair manner, about 80% of the maximum unfairness imaginable.

_Method:_
- The [[Factor|Object|FabFactor]] uses 'Article A' as the primary [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] and 'Person B' as the related [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].
- The Descriptor uses the 'Refers To' [[DescriptorType|Enum|DescriptorType]]. 
- The Vector uses the 'Fairness' [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]] as the axis, the 'Opposable Favorability' [[VectorType|Enum|VectorType]], '-80' as the value, the default 'Base' [[VectorUnitPrefix|Enum|VectorUnitPrefix]], and the default 'None' [[VectorUnit|Enum|VectorUnit]]. This [[VectorType|Enum|VectorType]] has bounds of -100 to +100.

_Factor Phrase:_
Article A ... Refers To ... Person B, ... (which, along the) Fairness (axis) ... (with a) Opposable Favorabillity (numerical range), ... (has a value) '-80'.)]

Properties.Name: Type
Properties.Description: Specifies its value's 'sboundaries and context.

Properties.Name: Unit
Properties.Description: Specifies its value's 'sunit of measurement.

Properties.Name: UnitPrefix
Properties.Description: Specifies its value's 'sorder of magnitude.

Properties.Name: Value
Properties.Description: An integral value which is to be plotted along the specified axis. This value must account for the choice of prefix. After being multiplied by the prefix magnitude, the value must fall within the bounds specified by [[VectorType|Enum|VectorType]]. Before prefix multiplication, this value must be between –9,223,372,036,854,775,808 and 9,223,372,036,854,775,807.

Services.Name: Oauth
Services.Summary: Authenticate [[Apps|Object|FabApp]] and/or [[Users|Object|FabUser]] using various flows based on the Oauth 2.0 specification.
Services.Description: Authenticate [[Apps|Object|FabApp]] and/or [[Users|Object|FabUser]] using various flows based on the Oauth 2.0 specification.

Operations.Name: AccessToken
Operations.Description:
Get an OAuth access token using one of four 'flows'.  Fabric offers separate requests for these access token flows, but also provides this generic request for compatibility with the OAuth 2.0 specification.  See the other access token flows (such as the '[[Client Credentials|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenClientCredentials]]' flow) for information about the available OAuth flows.

An OAuth access token must be included with every Fabric API request (with the exception of the OAuth requests).  This token is the result of a successful login, an accepted [[App|Object|FabApp]] scope, a confirmed [[App|Object|FabApp]] secret code, and a confirmed authorization code.  Thus, each token is associated with a specific [[App|Object|FabApp]], [[User|Object|FabUser]], and successful OAuth process.  When included with an API request, Fabric obtains the relevant [[App|Object|FabApp]] and [[User|Object|FabUser]] ID values, and generates a response accordingly.

See [[FabOauthAccess|Object|FabOauthAccess]] for information on how to include an OAuth access token with a Fabric API request.

Parameters.Name: grant_type
Parameters.Description: Defines the desired access token flow.  The three accepted (case-sensitive) values are '[[authorization_code|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenAuthCode]]', '[[refresh|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenRefresh]]', and '[[client_credentials|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenClientCredentials]]'.

Parameters.Name: client_id
Parameters.Description: The [[App|Object|FabApp]] ID value (an integer) for the [[App|Object|FabApp]] making the request. This parameter is only used by the '[[Client Credentials|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenClientCredentials]]' flow.

Parameters.Name: client_secret
Parameters.Description: The alpha-numeric Secret for the [[App|Object|FabApp]] making the request. This verifies that the [[App|Object|FabApp]] itself is making the request, and not an imposter.  For this reason, the secret code should not be shared with anyone.

Parameters.Name: code
Parameters.Description: The authorization code obtained after a successful OAuth entry process. This parameter is only used by the '[[Authorization Code|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenAuthCode]]' flow.

Parameters.Name: refresh_token
Parameters.Description: The refresh token obtained after a successful '[[Authorization Code|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenAuthCode]]' access token flow.  A refresh token only applies to [[User|Object|FabUser]]-based OAuth sessions, not for [[App|Object|FabApp]]-based OAuth sessions.  This parameter is only used by the '[[Refresh|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenRefresh]]' flow.

Parameters.Name: redirect_uri
Parameters.Description: This value must be exactly the same as the redirect URI provided for the OAuth entry process.

Operations.Name: AccessTokenAuthCode
Operations.Description:
This OAuth flow should be used immediately after obtaining an authorization code from the OAuth entry process. Fabric verifies the authorization code, determines the associated [[App|Object|FabApp]] and [[User|Object|FabUser]] IDs, and generates a new access token.

See [[Access Token|Oper|Oauth.AccessToken]] for general information about the OAuth process.

Parameters.Name: code
Parameters.Description: The authorization code obtained after a successful OAuth entry process. This parameter is only used by the '[[Authorization Code|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenAuthCode]]' flow.

Parameters.Name: client_secret
Parameters.Description: The alpha-numeric Secret for the [[App|Object|FabApp]] making the request. This verifies that the [[App|Object|FabApp]] itself is making the request, and not an imposter.  For this reason, the secret code should not be shared with anyone.

Parameters.Name: redirect_uri
Parameters.Description: This value must be exactly the same as the redirect URI provided for the OAuth entry process.

Operations.Name: AccessTokenRefresh
Operations.Description:
This OAuth flow should be used to refresh an expired access token. If the refresh token is valid, Fabric generates new access and refresh tokens for the given OAuth session. This process also invalidates the original refresh token.

[[App|Object|FabApp]]-only access tokens (obtained with the '[[Client Credentials|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenClientCredentials]]' flow) should not be refreshed; the [[App|Object|FabApp]] should simply request a new access token.

See [[Access Token|Oper|Oauth.AccessToken]] for general information about the OAuth process.

Parameters.Name: refresh_token
Parameters.Description: The refresh token obtained after a successful '[[Authorization Code|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenAuthCode]]' access token flow.  A refresh token only applies to [[User|Object|FabUser]]-based OAuth sessions, not for [[App|Object|FabApp]]-based OAuth sessions.  This parameter is only used by the '[[Refresh|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenRefresh]]' flow.

Parameters.Name: client_secret
Parameters.Description: The alpha-numeric Secret for the [[App|Object|FabApp]] making the request. This verifies that the [[App|Object|FabApp]] itself is making the request, and not an imposter.  For this reason, the secret code should not be shared with anyone.

Parameters.Name: redirect_uri
Parameters.Description: This value must be exactly the same as the redirect URI provided for the OAuth entry process.

Operations.Name: AccessTokenClientCredentials
Operations.Description:
This OAuth flow should be used to begin an OAuth session for your Fabric [[App|Object|FabApp]]. This flow does not require an authorization code from the typical OAuth entry process.

See [[Access Token|Oper|Oauth.AccessToken]] or general information about the OAuth process.

Parameters.Name: client_id
Parameters.Description: The [[App|Object|FabApp]] ID value (an integer) for the [[App|Object|FabApp]] making the request. This parameter is only used by the '[[Client Credentials|Oper|Oauth.AccessTokenClientCredentials]]' flow.

Parameters.Name: client_secret
Parameters.Description: The alpha-numeric Secret for the [[App|Object|FabApp]] making the request. This verifies that the [[App|Object|FabApp]] itself is making the request, and not an imposter.  For this reason, the secret code should not be shared with anyone.

Parameters.Name: redirect_uri
Parameters.Description: This value must be exactly the same as the redirect URI provided for the OAuth entry process.

Operations.Name: Login
Operations.Description:
This API request is unique -- it represents the entry point for Fabric's 'sOAuth 2.0 authentication process.  Instead of making this API request directly from a Fabric [[App|Object|FabApp]], the [[App|Object|FabApp]] should provide a link so that its users can load this request's 'sURL (including the required query-string parameters) in their browser.

A web-based Fabric [[App|Object|FabApp]] would typically load this OAuth entry page as a browser popup window. Once the user completes the full OAuth process (or upon an error), Fabric will redirect the browser to the [[App|Object|FabApp]]'s 'sspecified redirect URI.  This redirect includes query-string parameters that provide success or error information.
	
For a user, this OAuth process includes two steps: login and 'scope' acceptance.

The first step is login, where the user is prompted to enter their username and password. If a user has already logged into Fabric (i.e. has an active authentication cookie from Fabric) and the [[App|Object|FabApp]] has not requested 'switchMode', the login step is skipped.  Important note: login occurs on Fabric's 'sserver -- a Fabric [[App|Object|FabApp]] never receives or sends a Fabric user's 'slogin credentials.

The second step is 'scope' acceptance.  The page tells the user that a particular Fabric [[App|Object|FabApp]] wants to connect to their Fabric account, and briefly explains what this means to the user and the [[App|Object|FabApp]]. The user must accept or deny access.  Upon acceptance, the page redirects to the [[App|Object|FabApp]] with a 'success' message.  Upon denial, Fabric performs an error redirect.
	
Similar to the login step, if a user has already accepted 'scope' for a particular [[App|Object|FabApp]], the second step is skipped.  Thus, in the case where a user is already authenticated with Fabric and has already allowed [[App|Object|FabApp]] access, the entire process results in a success redirect.
	
See FabOauthLogin for the query string parameters that can be included in the success and error redirects.

Parameters.Name: response_type
Parameters.Description: Describes which type of authentication should be performed. For now, this value should always be 'code'. Fabric may accept more response types in the future.

Parameters.Name: client_id
Parameters.Description: The ID of the Fabric [[App|Object|FabApp]] making the OAuth Login request.  The access code provided after a successful OAuth process will be associated with this [[App|Object|FabApp]] ID and the authenticated [[User|Object|FabUser]]'s 'sID.

Parameters.Name: redirect_uri
Parameters.Description: The URL which will receive success/error redirects from the OAuth Login process.  This URL should handle the following query-string parameters: access_code, error, error_description, state.

Parameters.Name: scope
Parameters.Description: Describes the level of access the [[App|Object|FabApp]] will have to the [[User|Object|FabUser]]'s 'saccount.  This value is required by the OAuth 2.0 specification, however, Fabric currently ignores it.  All OAuth requests currently receive the same level of access to the [[User|Object|FabUser]]'s 'saccount.  Fabric may begin using this parameter in the future.

Parameters.Name: state
Parameters.Description: Provides a security function for a Fabric [[App|Object|FabApp]].  All success/message redirect responses include a 'state' query-string parameter.  The [[App|Object|FabApp]] should check this value against the state value provided in the initial request.  The two values should always be equal. If the values are not equal, then the redirect did not come from the Fabric OAuth process (or from a different user's 'sprocess), and should be handled accordingly.

Parameters.Name: switchMode
Parameters.Description: Causes the login process to behave in different ways.  If a value of '1' is provided, the user will see the login page even if they are currently authenticated with Fabric.  This is useful shared-computer scenarios, where the most-recently authenticated user may be different from the user making the current request.

Operations.Name: Logout
Operations.Description:
Terminates a particular OAuth session by invalidating the session's 'saccess token. Any further OAuth requests made with this particular access token are rejected.

Logging out of an OAuth session does not revoke the the [[App|Object|FabApp]] scope accepted by the [[User|Object|FabUser]] (during the first OAuth login process).  Furthermore, it does not end the [[User|Object|FabUser]]'s 'sauthenticated session with Fabric.  Thus, a subsequent OAuth entry by the same user may actually require zero input from the user -- they could potentially bypass both OAuth entry steps (login and scope acceptance).  This allows a user to begin a new OAuth session seamlessly, even after logging out.

Parameters.Name: access_token
Parameters.Description: The access token for the desired OAuth session. This request will fail if the token has already been invalidated by a previous logout.

Services.Summary: Query the Fabric graph using predefined traversal steps and functions.
Services.Description: Query the Fabric graph using predefined traversal steps and functions.

Steps.Name: With
Steps.Description: Finds results where the target property is an exact match to the specified value.

Parameters.Name: Value
Parameters.Description: The exact value to match for this search.

Steps.Name: Where
Steps.Description: Finds results where the target property is within the specified range of values.

Parameters.Name: Operation
Parameters.Description: The operator that defines the type of range to use for this search. Options include: "Greater Than", "Less Than or Equal", "Not Equal", etc.

Parameters.Name: Value
Parameters.Description: The boundary value for the search range.

Steps.Name: WhereContains
Steps.Description: Finds results where the target property contains one or more of the specified tokens.

Parameters.Name: Tokens
Parameters.Description: The space-delimited, case-insensitive search tokens.

Steps.Name: Active
Steps.Description: Finds results based on the authenticated state of this traversal request.

Steps.Name: Take
Steps.Description: Restricts the number of results at the current traversal step.

Parameters.Name: Count
Parameters.Description: The maximum number of elements to return.

Steps.Name: As
Steps.Description: Creates a named alias for the current step of the traversal path. Execution of the traversal path can return to this alias using the [[Back|Step|Back]] step.

Parameters.Name: Alias
Parameters.Description: A named alias, which represents a particular place in the traversal path. This value must be unique across all other aliases in the traversal path.

Steps.Name: Back
Steps.Description:
Returns the execution of the traversal path to a particular named alias. This alias is created using the [[As|Step|As]] step.

When traversal execution reaches a Back step, the execution retraces (steps backwards through) the traversal path until the alias is reached. Execution then proceeds using the traversal step(s) that immediately follow the Back function step.

The return type of the Back step is determined by the return type of the corresponding alias.
[(EX|Return Type Example|_Traversal Steps_
Get a list of Members:
- /!Root/ContainsMemberList/As(M)

Get a list of [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]] created by those Members:
- /!Root/ContainsMemberList/As(M)/CreatesArtifactList

Retrace to the "M" alias, which returns Members:
- /!Root/ContainsMemberList/As(M)/CreatesArtifactList/Back(M))]

When execution retraces the traversal path, it does so _only_ from the vertices that are currently active at the Back step. This makes the Back step useful for complex filtering.

[(EX|Retrace Example|_Objective_
Find all the [[Members|Object|FabMember]] of a particular [[App|Object|FabApp]] (AppId = 123) that have created at least one [[Artifact|Object|FabArtifact]].

_Traversal Steps_
Create named alias "M" at the [[Member|Object|FabMember]] step:
- /!Root/ContainsMemberList/As(M)

Continue traversing to the target App:
- /!Root/ContainsMemberList/As(M)/InAppDefines/HasId(2)

Retrace to the [[Member|Object|FabMember]] list, which now contains only [[Members|Object|FabMember]] of "Great App":
- /!Root/ContainsMemberList/As(M)/InAppDefines/HasId(2)/Back(M)

Continue traversing to the [[Artifacts|Object|FabArtifact]] created by these Members:
- /!Root/ContainsMemberList/As(M)/InAppDefines/HasId(2)/Back(M)/CreatesArtifactList

Retrace to the [[Member|Object|FabMember]] list, which now also excludes any [[Members|Object|FabMember]] who have not created an Artifact:
- /!Root/ContainsMemberList/As(M)/InAppDefines/HasId(2)/Back(M)/CreatesArtifactList/Back(M))]

Parameters.Name: Alias
Parameters.Description: The target named alias, which was defined by an [[As|Func|As]] function earlier in the traversal path.

Steps.Name: To
Steps.Description: Restricts the results to include only [[App|Object|FabApp]] vertices.

Steps.Name: Link
Steps.Description:
Traverses along an Edge type (connection) between one [[Vertex|Object|FabVertex]] and zero, one, or many others.

Links which will produce many results require further filtering (via relevant FabLink item) before arriving at the desired [[Vertex|Object|FabVertex]] items. To complete this filtering, use the relevant [[Take|Step|Take]] step.

Items.Name: Is Related To
Items.Description: The primary Artifact is related to the related Artifact in some way. This is the default (and least meaningful) DescriptorType.

Items.Name: Is (A/An)
Items.Description: The primary Artifact is a type of, a subclass of, a subset of, a subordinate of, or in the category defined by the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Is An Instance Of
Items.Description: The primary Artifact is an instance, case, example, or representation of the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Has (A/An)
Items.Description: The primary Artifact has, as a part, piece, feature, attribute, or component, the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Is Like
Items.Description: The primary Artifact is like or similar to the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Is Not Like
Items.Description: The primary Artifact is not like or not similar to the related Artifact

Items.Name: Refers To
Items.Description: The primary Artifact refers to, mentions, discusses, links to, or references the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Is Created By
Items.Description: The primary Artifact is created, built, designed, invented, formed, or performed by the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Is Interested In
Items.Description: The primary Artifact is interested in, fond of, attracted to, enjoys, prefers, or desires the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Receives
Items.Description: The primary Artifact receives, gets, obtains, or is awarded the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Consumes
Items.Description: The primary Artifact consumes, eats, is powered by, uses up, depletes, or destroys the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Produces
Items.Description: The primary Artifact produces, has a byproduct of, creates, or generates the related Artifact. This is similar to 'Is Created By', but in the opposite direction and meant to be less specific.

Items.Name: Participates In
Items.Description: The primary Artifact participates in, competes in, attends, is a member of, or is involved in the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Is Found In
Items.Description: The primary Artifact is found in, located at, lives in, or is contained by the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Belongs To
Items.Description: The primary Artifact belongs to, is controlled by, or is owned by the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Requires
Items.Description: The primary Artifact requires, implies, needs, or demands the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Interacts With
Items.Description: The primary Artifact interacts, associates, combines, meets, or communicates with the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Looks Like
Items.Description: The primary Artifact looks like (has the appearance of) the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Smells Like
Items.Description: The primary Artifact smells like (has the odor, aroma, or fragrance of) the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Tastes Like
Items.Description: The primary Artifact tastes like (has the flavor of) the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Sounds Like
Items.Description: The primary Artifact sounds like (has the aural characteristics of) the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Feels Like
Items.Description: The primary Artifact feels like (has the tactile characteristics of) the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Emotes Like
Items.Description: The primary Artifact emotes like (causes the emotion of) the related Artifact.

Items.Name: Uses
Items.Description: The primary Artifact uses, utilizes, controls, employs, or manipulates the related Artifact.

Items.Description: A coordinate position on Earth's Moon.Coordinates use X=Longitude, Y=Latitude, and Z=Elevation (in metres).Coordinates use X=Longitude, Y=Latitude, and Z=Elevation (in metres).

Items.Name: Mars Coordinate
Items.Description: A coordinate position on Mars.Coordinates use X=Longitude, Y=Latitude, and Z=Elevation (in metres).Coordinates use X=Longitude, Y=Latitude, and Z=Elevation (in metres).

Items.Name: Relative Position 1D
Items.Description: A one-dimensional position, using X=Time. A position is relative to the Artifact's dimensions. For example, X=0.25 represents a position (starting from the origin) that is 25% of the distance to the maximum X dimension.

Items.Name: Relative Position 2D
Items.Description: A two-dimensional position, using X=Width and Y=Height. A position is relative to the Artifact's dimensions. For example, X=0.25 represents a position (starting from the origin) that is 25% of the distance to the maximum X dimension.

Items.Name: Relative Position 3D
Items.Description: A three-dimensional position, using X, Y, and Z axes. A position is relative to the Artifact's dimensions. For example, X=0.25 represents a position (starting from the origin) that is 25% of the distance to the maximum X dimension.
